title: Bazel silently crashes on Windows while starting the server with `--client_debug` option

labels.name: P2
labels.description: We'll consider working on this in future. (Assignee optional)

labels.name: team-Core
labels.description: Skyframe, bazel query, BEP, options parsing, bazelrc

body:
### Description of the bug:


Bazel silently crashes on any command under the following conditions:
- Windows
- Bazel built with static C++ runtime linking
- Bazel server has not been started
- startup option `--client_debug` specified

The expected behavior:
- Bazel successfully executes the command under the conditions above
- in case of crash it reports the error to a user

### Which category does this issue belong to?

Core

### What's the simplest, easiest way to reproduce this bug? Please provide a minimal example if possible.


1. Build Bazel from the source code with static C++ runtime linking:
`bazel.exe build --compilation_mode=opt //src:bazel.exe -s --stamp --embed_label=8.3.1-000 --features=static_link_msvcrt`
2. Ensure that Bazel server is not running:
`bazel.exe --client_debug shutdown`
3. Build any target with `--client_debug` option:
`bazel.exe --client_debug build //examples/windows/dll:hellolib`

The output of last command:
```
[INFO 18:17:40.539 src/main/cpp/rc_file.cc:62] Parsing the RcFile c:\github\bazelbuild/.bazelrc
[INFO 18:17:40.540 src/main/cpp/rc_file.cc:126] Skipped optional import of %workspace%/user.bazelrc, the specified rc file either does not exist oris not readable.
[INFO 18:17:40.541 src/main/cpp/blaze_util_windows.cc:1457] python.exe found on PATH: C:\tools\Python311\python.exe
[INFO 18:17:40.541 src/main/cpp/blaze.cc:1649] Debug logging requested, sending all client log statements to stderr
[INFO 18:17:40.542 src/main/cpp/blaze.cc:1652] Running (pid=31384)
[INFO 18:17:40.544 src/main/cpp/blaze.cc:1510] Acquired the client lock, waited 0 milliseconds
[USER 18:17:41.469 src/main/cpp/blaze.cc:958] Starting local Bazel server (8.3.1-000) and connecting to it...

```
At this point Bazel exits without building the target.

### Which operating system are you running Bazel on?


Windows

### What is the output of `bazel info release`?


_No response_

### If `bazel info release` returns `development version` or `(@non-git)`, tell us how you built Bazel.


_No response_

### What's the output of `git remote get-url origin; git rev-parse HEAD` ?


```text

```

### If this is a regression, please try to identify the Bazel commit where the bug was introduced with bazelisk --bisect.


The issue was found on version 8.3.1 and is reproducible on latest master. It has not been observed on 7.6.1.
Very likely, the problem is related to this commit:
https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/commit/1744d45c0c57af23f631c2145e8af4b185dca77f



### Have you found anything relevant by searching the web?

_No response_

### Any other information, logs, or outputs that you want to share?

Debugging showed that crash happens at this point:
https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/blob/1967cb02e7c77263c5bdbb89cc1e0fcacf0a7409/src/main/cpp/blaze.cc#L1315
because the value of `environ` at line above is NULL. Also, we have found that `environ` is always NULL, from start of program and until this point.
But in case when we do not specify `--client_debug` option, the value of `environ` became valid at this point:
https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/blob/e3802cfa72433649b5d695b2011a355fcae4c745/src/main/cpp/blaze_util.cc#L247

I believe that origin of the issue is using a `wmain` function on Windows instead of `main`. According to [this article](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/c-language/using-wmain?view=msvc-170):
`Similarly, if your program uses a wmain function, a wide-character environment is created at program startup and is pointed to by the _wenviron global variable. An MBCS (ASCII) environment is created on the first call to _putenv or getenv, and is pointed to by the _environ global variable.`
So, an ASCII environment is not initially created until the `getenv()` call somewhere inside `absl::InitializeLog()`.

The workaround is placing a dummy `getenv()` call in `wmain` function. This resolves the issue.
However, I believe you might prefer to use a wide-character version of environment with `_wenviron` global variable.
